subject: probability
title: Central Limit Theorem
contentHtml:
The Central Limit Theorem (CLT) is a cornerstone of probability theory.

It states that given certain conditions, the distribution of the mean of i.i.d. random variables will converge to a normal distribution as the sample size increases.

theorem.proofSketch: The proof typically involves showing that the sum of i.i.d. random variables is asymptotically normal using characteristic functions or moment methods.

intuition: The CLT provides a powerful tool for modeling real-world phenomena, as many natural processes involve averaging over large numbers of observations.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, the CLT is used to justify the use of Gaussian distributions in modeling and inference.

title: Central Limit Theorem
contentHtml: The Central Limit Theorem (CLT) is a cornerstone of probability theory, stating that under certain conditions, the distribution of the mean of i.i.d. random variables converges to a normal distribution as the sample size increases.

theorem.proofSketch: The proof involves showing that the sum of i.i.d. random variables is approximately normally distributed by applying the Lindeberg-Feller CLT and then using the Berry-Esseen theorem to establish the rate of convergence.

intuition: In essence, the CLT says that as you average more and more independent observations, the distribution of those averages becomes increasingly normal. This has far-reaching implications in statistics, machine learning, and data analysis.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, the CLT is used to justify the use of Gaussian distributions in modeling real-world phenomena.
